This wrapper really needs a better tutorial and simple examples. I'm trying to run

from trello.board import Board, BoardProvider

and it doesn't work because: 

ImportError: cannot import name 'BoardProvider'

And boards is unresolved..

I'm giving up. Not that it's too complicated in the absolute but because it's really time consuming and instead of using the trello API and try to achieve something that I need, I'm struggling to just get py-trello working. Not my day time job, so it's really frustrating.

Hope you will get arround that.

data.text: Clickable link for convenience: https://github.com/sarumont/py-trello

Looks like this is already done. :-)

    def comment(self, comment_text):
        """Add a comment to a card."""
        self.client.fetch_json(
            '/cards/' + self.id + '/actions/comments',
            http_method='POST',
            post_args={'text': comment_text, })

data.text: I'm quite new to python but I've installed http2 and ouath and py-trello but I have no idea what trello client is and how I import it, where I store the key info or how to run py-trello. Could someone explain these bits please?

I just found py-trello today and am having some success with it. One comment is that maybe the Checklist.__init__ method should actually be Checklist._from_json or something, like the Client class when you fetch a board.  I was thinking that because it would be nice to construct a new Checklist and add it to the Card.

Another thing I did in my code was to add Board.get_members() so I could subscribe board members to a new card.

Good stuff!  Thanks!

Hi Alex,  
Take a look at the addAttachment() method here https://github.com/plish/Trolly/blob/master/trello/card.py you need to send the file as multipart form data. Hope that helps.  
  
Luke

Hi Richard,

I'm interested to use py-trello, but I really need attachments.
Ilooked around, it seems that attachments are supported in the trello API:

https://trello.com/docs/api/card/index.html#post-1-cards-card-id-or-shortlink-attachments

I managed to successfully add attachments using the 'url' argument by adding this function to the Card class:


        def attach_url(self, url):
                self.client.fetch_json(
                        '/cards/'+self.id+'/attachments',
                        http_method = 'POST',
                        post_args = {'url' : url, })

I'm no web-app expert though, so I couldn't figure out how to extend this to attaching a file from disk.
Does anyone understand how to do this?

Thanks,

Alex
It is possible with the Trello API to upload a new image into a card and delete an existing one? (assuming write privileges)

card.name: Add setup.py
card.desc:
Would be nice if you added a **setup.py** allowing to install py-trello with pip as a 3rd-part app. Uploading it to PyPI would be even better.

I'd be able to use it from [Trello-Git](https://trello.com/board/trello-git/4f6a76f4801cba2d415aea1f) much more easily.

Thanks !

data.text: I apologize if those features have already been implemented and I overlooked them

I wound up not needing write permission and instead only needing to read from my boards. I'd like to archive them at some point too so I'll eventually work on helping to implement that. I'm not sure how to 2-legged auth, though I did look around a bit. I can dig more later. 

Here's the information I got from __init__.py. I tried regenerating my 3 legged auth a few different time with read/write privileges. No luck so far.

Resource unavailable: https://api.trello.com/1/lists/4ef7acec10e1ff150b0bf338/cards?key=f76f72a5c032a419bc541e08f1cbce7a&token=a588984bae73e7180d2c840e036cf15d2ea4adf778a2483c056a3ca914818153
E{'status': '401', 'content-length': '13', 'x-powered-by': 'Express', 'connection': 'keep-alive', 'access-control-allow-origin': '*', 'access-control-allow-methods': 'GET, PUT, POST, DELETE', 'content-type': 'text/plain; charset=utf-8'}
Status: 401
Content: unauthorized

Hrm - Are you trying to use 3-legged oauth? Does it work with a 2-legged token?

You can log/print the exact response in __init__.py to see what the server is returning.
Did some research. Looks like you've encountered this before in some other flavor. Did I not correctly patch oauth2 or generate an incomplete API key?
I'm going through and trying to debug at the moment. the url looks valid to me...
